--- title: Exploratory data analysis subtitle: Lecture 4 format: revealjs: default editor_options: chunk_output_type: console execute: warning: false message: false --- ## Setup ::: {#setup .cell message='false' execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} # Import all required libraries import pandas as pd import numpy as np import seaborn as sns import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import scipy.stats as stats from scipy.stats import skewnorm from scipy.stats import kurtosis, norm from scipy.stats import gamma import missingno as msno import random import statsmodels.api as sm # Load in UK Smoking Data births14 = pd.read_csv("data/births14.csv") # Set seed random.seed(123) ``` ::: # Exploratory Data Analysis ## What is exploratory data analysis? {.smaller} > Exploratory Data Analysis is a statistical approach to analyzing datasets to summarize their main characteristics, often using visual methods. ## Examining data {.smaller} ::: panel-tabset ## Head ::: {#4c8f67d9 .cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} births14.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=2} ```{=html}
fage mage mature weeks premie visits gained weight lowbirthweight sex habit marital whitemom
0 34.0 34 younger mom 37 full term 14.0 28.0 6.96 not low male nonsmoker married white
1 36.0 31 younger mom 41 full term 12.0 41.0 8.86 not low female nonsmoker married white
2 37.0 36 mature mom 37 full term 10.0 28.0 7.51 not low female nonsmoker married not white
3 NaN 16 younger mom 38 full term NaN 29.0 6.19 not low male nonsmoker not married white
4 32.0 31 younger mom 36 premie 12.0 48.0 6.75 not low female nonsmoker married white
``` ::: ::: ## Info ::: {#917aef63 .cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} births14.info() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` RangeIndex: 1000 entries, 0 to 999 Data columns (total 13 columns): # Column Non-Null Count Dtype --- ------ -------------- ----- 0 fage 886 non-null float64 1 mage 1000 non-null int64 2 mature 1000 non-null object 3 weeks 1000 non-null int64 4 premie 1000 non-null object 5 visits 944 non-null float64 6 gained 958 non-null float64 7 weight 1000 non-null float64 8 lowbirthweight 1000 non-null object 9 sex 1000 non-null object 10 habit 981 non-null object 11 marital 1000 non-null object 12 whitemom 1000 non-null object dtypes: float64(4), int64(2), object(7) memory usage: 101.7+ KB ``` ::: ::: ## Describe ::: {#d089b6d3 .cell execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} births14.describe() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=4} ```{=html}
fage mage weeks visits gained weight
count 886.000000 1000.000000 1000.000000 944.000000 958.000000 1000.000000
mean 31.133183 28.449000 38.666000 11.351695 30.425887 7.198160
std 7.058135 5.759737 2.564961 4.108192 15.242527 1.306775
min 15.000000 14.000000 21.000000 0.000000 0.000000 0.750000
25% 26.000000 24.000000 38.000000 9.000000 20.000000 6.545000
50% 31.000000 28.000000 39.000000 12.000000 30.000000 7.310000
75% 35.000000 33.000000 40.000000 14.000000 38.000000 8.000000
max 85.000000 47.000000 46.000000 30.000000 98.000000 10.620000
``` ::: ::: ::: ## Visualizing data relationships {.smaller} ::: {#36b6db01 .cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.pairplot(births14[['fage', 'mage', 'weeks', 'mature']], hue='mature', height=2) plt.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](04-eda_files/figure-revealjs/cell-6-output-1.png){width=717 height=570} ::: ::: ## Group descriptive statistics {.smaller} ::: {#fb1344d4 .cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} # Example with the premie column births14.groupby('premie').describe() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=6} ```{=html}
fage mage ... gained weight
count mean std min 25% 50% 75% max count mean ... 75% max count mean std min 25% 50% 75% max
premie
full term 775.0 30.967742 6.681591 15.0 26.0 31.0 35.0 49.0 876.0 28.329909 ... 38.0 98.0 876.0 7.434178 1.021699 3.93 6.77 7.44 8.0825 10.62
premie 111.0 32.288288 9.226826 15.0 27.0 32.0 36.0 85.0 124.0 29.290323 ... 41.0 85.0 124.0 5.530806 1.801182 0.75 4.50 5.75 6.5725 9.25

2 rows Ã— 48 columns

``` ::: ::: ## Outliers {.smaller} Outliers are data points that are significantly different from others. Identifying and handling outliers is important in data analysis. ![](images/outliers.png){fig-align="center" width="877"} ::: fragment > Outliers = 1.5 \* Interquartile range ::: ## Assess outliers visually {.smaller} ::: {#0f3a0174 .cell execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} sns.boxplot(data = births14, x = 'weight', width = 0.20) plt.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](04-eda_files/figure-revealjs/cell-8-output-1.png){width=768 height=429 fig-align='center'} ::: ::: ## Find outliers {.smaller} ::: panel-tabset ## Output ::: {#581520ba .cell execution_count=8} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` fage: 7 outliers mage: 1 outliers weeks: 72 outliers visits: 30 outliers gained: 26 outliers weight: 32 outliers ``` ::: ::: ## Code ::: {#6744cff8 .cell execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} for column in births14.select_dtypes(include=np.number).columns: q25 = births14[column].quantile(0.25) q75 = births14[column].quantile(0.75) iqr = q75 - q25 lower_bound = q25 - 1.5 * iqr upper_bound = q75 + 1.5 * iqr outliers = births14[(births14[column] < lower_bound) | (births14[column] > upper_bound)] print(f"{column}: {outliers.shape[0]} outliers") ``` ::: ::: ::: fragment - `q25`: 1/4 quartile, 25th percentile; `q75`: 3/4 quartile, 75th percentile - `IQR`: interquartile range, $IQR = q75-q25$ - `lower`; `upper`: lower, upper limit of $1.5\times IQR$ used to calculate outliers ::: ## Remove outliers {.smaller} ::: panel-tabset ## Cleaning ::: {#4db671df .cell execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code code-line-numbers="1-14|2|4|6,7,8|10,11|13"} # Select numerical columns numerical_cols = births14.select_dtypes(include = ['number']).columns for col in numerical_cols: # Find Q1, Q3, and interquartile range (IQR) for each column Q1 = births14[col].quantile(0.25) Q3 = births14[col].quantile(0.75) IQR = Q3 - Q1 # Upper and lower bounds for each column lower_bound = Q1 - 1.5 * IQR upper_bound = Q3 + 1.5 * IQR # Filter out the outliers from the DataFrame births14_clean = births14[(births14[col] >= lower_bound) & (births14[col] <= upper_bound)] ``` ::: ## Plot ::: {#7fd5cb7f .cell execution_count=11} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](04-eda_files/figure-revealjs/cell-12-output-1.png){width=768 height=429 fig-align='center'} ::: ::: ::: ::: fragment #### Why are there still outliers? ::: ## Missing values (`NaN`) ::: {#7c1a4ca0 .cell execution_count=12} ``` {.python .cell-code} # Count missing values in each column births14.isnull().sum() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=11} ``` fage 114 mage 0 mature 0 weeks 0 premie 0 visits 56 gained 42 weight 0 lowbirthweight 0 sex 0 habit 19 marital 0 whitemom 0 dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: ## Visualizing (`NaN`) {.smaller} We can use the `missingno` library to visualize missing data. ::: {#399ca807 .cell execution_count=13} ``` {.python .cell-code} msno.bar(births14, figsize = (7, 5), fontsize = 10) plt.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](04-eda_files/figure-revealjs/cell-14-output-1.png){width=614 height=520 fig-align='center'} ::: ::: ## Describe categorical variables {.smaller} ::: panel-tabset ## Describe ::: {#03b12da8 .cell execution_count=14} ``` {.python .cell-code} births14.describe(exclude = [np.number]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=13} ```{=html}
mature premie lowbirthweight sex habit marital whitemom
count 1000 1000 1000 1000 981 1000 1000
unique 2 2 2 2 2 2 2
top younger mom full term not low male nonsmoker married white
freq 841 876 919 505 867 594 765
``` ::: ::: ## Unique levels ::: {#9ccf4c02 .cell execution_count=15} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` mature: ['younger mom' 'mature mom'] premie: ['full term' 'premie'] lowbirthweight: ['not low' 'low'] sex: ['male' 'female'] habit: ['nonsmoker' 'smoker' nan] marital: ['married' 'not married'] whitemom: ['white' 'not white'] ``` ::: ::: ## Code ::: {#ac018538 .cell execution_count=16} ``` {.python .cell-code code-line-numbers="|1|2"} for column in births14.select_dtypes(include=['object', 'category']).columns: print(f"{column}: {births14[column].unique()}") ``` ::: ::: # Normality check ::: fragment Checking if the data follows a normal distribution is a common step in EDA. ::: ## Normality check {.smaller} ::: {#c9b15987 .cell execution_count=17} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](04-eda_files/figure-revealjs/cell-18-output-1.png){width=527 height=316 fig-align='center'} ::: ::: ::: fragment ::: incremental - **Histogram**: bell-shaped curve - **Skewness**: Close to 0 for symmetry; **Kurtosis**: Close to 3 for normal "tailedness." - **Sample Size**: Larger samples are less sensitive to non-normality. - **Empirical Rule**: 68-95-99.7% rule (1, 2, and 3 st dev. of the mean). ::: ::: ## Skewness {.smaller} ::: {#269c1522 .cell execution_count=18} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](04-eda_files/figure-revealjs/cell-19-output-1.png){width=961 height=391 fig-align='center'} ::: ::: ::: fragment ::: incremental - Several definitions - Sensitive to outliers - Designed for one peak (*unimodal*) ::: ::: ## Kurtosis {.smaller} ::: {#f47e1245 .cell execution_count=19} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](04-eda_files/figure-revealjs/cell-20-output-1.png){width=825 height=442 fig-align='center'} ::: ::: ::: fragment ::: incremental - Sensitive to outliers - Designed for one peak (*unimodal*) ::: ::: ## Q-Q plot {.smaller} ::: panel-tabset ## Normal ::: {#d4d77bae .cell fig.asp='0.618' fig.width='10' execution_count=21} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](04-eda_files/figure-revealjs/cell-22-output-1.png){width=820 height=442 fig-align='center'} ::: ::: ## Negative skew ::: {#3ba01617 .cell fig.asp='0.618' fig.width='10' execution_count=22} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](04-eda_files/figure-revealjs/cell-23-output-1.png){width=836 height=442 fig-align='center'} ::: ::: ## Positive skew ::: {#6dc844fa .cell fig.asp='0.618' fig.width='10' execution_count=23} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](04-eda_files/figure-revealjs/cell-24-output-1.png){width=836 height=442 fig-align='center'} ::: ::: ::: ## Testing normality: data shape {.smaller} ::: {#0a4489cb .cell execution_count=24} ``` {.python .cell-code code-fold="true" code-line-numbers="1-24|2,5|8|11|14|17,18|21-24"} # Make a copy of the data dataCopy = births14.copy() # Remove NAs dataCopyFin = dataCopy.dropna() # Q-Q plot sm.qqplot(dataCopyFin.weight, line='s') plt.title('Newborn Weight Q-Q plot') plt.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](04-eda_files/figure-revealjs/cell-25-output-1.png){width=820 height=464 fig-align='center'} ::: ::: ::: fragment **Negative-skew (left-tailed)** ::: ## Conclusions ::: incremental - Always inspect your data first. - Visualize relationships and distributions. - Identify and handle outliers and missing values. - Check for normality and understand the distribution of your data. ::: # We will add to this!
